Protocolos de extração de lipídeos:
1.1. Protocolo de extração de biomarcadores das amostras de sedimentos lacustres
1.2. Protocolo de extração de biomarcadores das amostras de guano
112
1.1. Protocolo de extração de biomarcadores das amostras de sedimentos lacustres
Freeze-drying samples
Use around 2g of dry sample
Extraction:
1. Add internal standards
2. Add 5ml of DCM/MeOH (3:1) into the vial (vial 1) with dry sediment
3. Vortex
4. Sonicate for 10 min.
5. Centrifuge 2 min at 3000 rpm
6. Pipette surnatant and transfer it into a second vial (vial 2)
7. Repeat twice
8. Dry solvent with N2 at 35°C
Saponification:
9. Add 4 ml of 4M KOH/MeOH with 10% H2O (160ml MeOH, 40ml H2O and 49g of
KOH) into the vial with the extract
10. Put in the oven for 2h at 80°C
11. Confirm the pH of the solution (must be high)
Separate neutral fraction from TLE (Total lipid extract)
12. Add 3ml of hexane
13. Vortex
14. Centrifuge 2 min at 3000 rpm
15. Pipette surnatant (organic phase) and transfer it to a new vial (vial 3)
16. Repeat twice
17. Dry solvent with N2 at 35°C (vial 3)
Separate acidic fraction from TLE
18. After remove the neutral fraction, acidify the solution in the vial 2, dropping 4ml of
HCL solution (6M).
19. Confirm the pH of the solution (must be low).
20. Add 2ml hexane/Ethyl Acetate (9:1 v/v)
21. Vortex
22. Centrifuge 2min at 3000 rpm
23. Pipette surnatant (organic phase) and transfer it into a new vial (vial 4)
24. Dry solvent with N2 at 35°C
Separation of neutral fraction into 4 fractions (with a silica column)
25. Add 1ml of hexane into the dried neutral fraction (vial 3)
26. Vortex
27. Prepare a silica column. Fill a short pipette with silica in hexane till 4 cm length.
28. Load the neutral fraction in approximately 0,5 ml of the misture (hexane + neutral
phase in the item 25)
29. Separate neutral fraction with 4 kinds of eluents:
1. Fraction 1 (F1): 4 ml of hexane for hydrocarbon (vial 5)
113
2. Fraction 2 (F2): Consist in two fractions put in the same vial (vial 6) for ketone,
aldehyde and ester
F2A: 2 ml of hexane/Ethyl Acetate (95:5)
F2B: 2 ml of hexane/Ethyl acetate (90:10)
3. Fraction 3 (F3): 5ml of hexane/Ethyl acetate (80:20) for alcohol and sterol
(vial7)
4. Fraction 4 (F4): 5 ml of DCM/MeOH (1:1) for more polar compounds (vial 8)
Methylation of Acidic Fraction
30. Dry the acidic fraction under N2
31. Add 100 µl of toluene + 1 ml of BF3 in the vial 4
32. Vortex
33. Inject Argon to remove O2
34. Put in the oven 1 hour at 80°C
35. After cooling, add 2 ml of satured solution of NaCl (400g/L)
36. Add 2 ml ether/hexane (1:1)
37. Vortex
38. Centrifuge 2 min at 3000 rpm
39. Pipette the organic phase and transfer it to a new vial (vial 9)
40. Repeat twice
41. Put 2 ml of Milliq water into vial 9
42. Vortex
43. Centrifuge 2 min at 3000 rpm
44. Remove the lower layer (aqueous phase) and discard
45. Repeat twice
46. Add in the organic extract (vial 9) anhydrous MgSO4
47. Vortex
48. Put one night in the fridge
49. Transfer the extract to a new vial (vial 10)
50. Rince the MgSO4 using ether/hexane (1:1)
51. Vortex
52. Centrifuge 2 min at 3000 rpm
53. Reapeat twice
54. Dry solvent with N2 at 35°C
Clean-up of acid fraction
1. Prepare a silica column. Put a small portion of clear cotton in the bottom of the
short pipette, fill it with silica in hexane till 4 cm length.
2. Rince the column with 4ml of DCM:hexane (2:1)
3. Load the acid fraction in approximately 0,5 ml of DCM:hexane (2:1)
4. Add the acid fraction into the column
5. Rince the column with 5ml of of DCM:hexane (2:1)
114
1.2. Protocolo de extração de biomarcadores das amostras de guano
Freeze-drying samples
Use around 6g of dry sample
Total lipid extraction:
1. Add internal standards
2. Add DCM/MeOH (3:1) into the vial (vial 1) with dry sediment

6. Pipette surnatant and transfer it into a second vial (vial 2)

9. Add 4 ml of 4M KOH/MeOH with 10% H2O (160ml MeOH, 40ml H2O and 24.5g

10. Confirm the pH of the solution before (must be high), put in the oven for 2h at

ABSTRACT
Although several studies contemplate the past interplay of fluvial and eolian systems, the
effects of fluvio-eolian interactions in costal humid climates have not been reported. In this
study, we analyze the Late Quaternary coastal evolution of the northeasternmost tip of the
Rio Grande do Norte (RN) State in Brazilian and the formation of the Boqueirão Lake that
was established when dune advancements started to interact with an ephemeral drainage
system in the Mid-Holocene. Analysis of a Boqueirão Lake core obtained in the path of a
seismic transect indicates changes in microfossil assemblages and sedimentological grain
size data that are synchronous with gradual fluvial damming from dune advancements.
Sedimentological data coupled with GPR surveys from dune advancements suggest that
eolian activity was primarily controlled by sediment availability since SE winds have been
strong through the Late Quaternary. In the RN coast, sediment availability is driven by
rainfall, that in turn is a function of the ITCZ position. The close-coupling of fluvio-eolian
interplay data not only improves our ability to read lacustrine environments under the
effect of geological processes, but also provides a valuable paleoenvironmental archive.
1. INTRODUCTION
119
The northesternmost coastal tip of the Rio Grande do Norte State (RN; Fig. 1) is
dominated by NW-trending active and stabilized dunefields, intermittent and ephemeral
small fluvial system and lakes. Presently, more than ten lakes are characterized by their
shallowness (<10 m) that is a function of seasonal rainfall (e.g. Gomes et al., 2014) with
minor contribution from groundwater. Recent studies in the Boqueirão Lake, situated in the
western boundary of the study area (Fig. 1) suggest that its past lake levels were also a
function of rainfall alone (Gomes et al., 2014; Zocatelli et al., 2012). However, this lake
eastern margin is bounded by stabilized dunes and the possibility of a genetic link with
fluvio-eolian interactions that affected lake levels cannot be disregarded. In fact, a common
type of fluvio-eolian interaction is associated with dune advancements that promote fluvial
natural dams (e.g. Al Mashary and Mountney, 2015; Liu and Coulthard, 2015; Loope and
Swinehart, 2000). Coastal lakes associated with dunes and ephemeral rivers are widespread
in coastal Brazil (e.g. Caçó Lake, Laranjal Lake). However, most paleoenvironmental
studies on these areas focus on their lacustrine archives alone (e.g. Sifeddine et al., 2003).
Also fluvial or eolian processes and their effects on coastal landforms are usually analyzed
independently (e.g. Fornari et al., 2012). Here, we examine the Late Quaternary evolution
of the northeastern coast of the RN state reconstructing the interplay of fluvio -eolian
systems. The response of fluvial systems to dune advancements is discussed and the case
of the Boqueirão Lake evolution is analyzed in detail.
1.1. Study area
The investigated coastal area is located in the northeastern tip of the Rio Grande do
Norte State (RN) in NE Brazil, on eastmost limit of South America (Fig. 1). The main city
in the region is Touros located at -5.192807 S, -35.467449 W. The study area encompasses
~650 km 2 of extensive SE- to NW active and stabilized dunefields under a 35 km coastal
stretch associated with the SE trade winds in the region (Fig. 1). Sand incursions reach as
far as the SW- to NE-oriented Boqueirão Lake that lies in the Boqueirão River pathway
and extend toward Touros city where it reaches the coast. The Boqueirão Lake is situated
13.5 km from the eastern RN coast and presents a maximum length width, depth, and
volume of 7 km, 0.6 km, 10 m, and 11,075 m 3 , respectively (e.g. Gomes et al., 2014) and is
succeeded on its western edge by laterites and sands from the Barreiras and Post-Barreiras
Neogene Formations (e.g. Angelim et al., 2006). The study area eastern edge is
characterized by beach erosion that is enhanced by the removal of sands to active coastal

1.2. Climate
Average yearly wind speeds data obtained at 50-m height are 8.5-9.0 m/s on the
foreshore and 8.0 m/s in the Boqueirão Lake ( Amarante et al, 2003). The prevailing SE
wind intensity is seasonal and controlled by an association of the SE Trade Winds, South
Touros city

Atlantic Anticyclone circulation, and sea breezes. Winds are stronger in the foreshore from
August to December, and weaker from January to July, with average values of 9 m/s, and 7
m/s, respectively (Amarante et al, 2003). Direction of propagation of oceanic wave fronts
is predominantely from SE and longoshore drift to the N (Bittencourt et al., 2005). Annual
mean temperature is 27 °C and climate is tropical semi-humid with annual mean
precipitation of 1200 mm and maximum rainfall recorded from May to July (Kousky,
1979). . Touros region is influenced by bimodal rainfall regime and receives significant
rainfall from March to May due to the presence of Intertropical Convergence Zone in the
region (Rao et al., 1993; 1996). From June to August the regional precipitation is
associated with the activity of atmospheric easterly waves (EWs) that associated with
intensification of SE trade winds. This process is especially important in eastern coast of
Nordeste whose limit coincides with Touros city. These EW winds blow in a direction
perpendicular to the ENEB coast and generate large amounts of rainfall in Nordeste but
this the precipitation is only distributed along the coast.
2. Methods
2.1. Sand incursion analyses
2.1.1. Field methods
The morphology of dune advancements and associated lakes and marshes were
initially studied using Google Earth images. To assess the timing of dune activity and
stabilization, 13 samples were collected for OSL dating at the the frontal lobe of the
parabolic dunes at 1-3 m below the surface to avoid bioturbation and any remaining active
dune crests (Fig. 2). Also, to identify previous cycles of dune encroachment 10 samples
were obtained at various depths and in three different exposed profiles (Fig. 2).
Additionally, these sites were surveyed using seven GPR transects to investigate dune
stratigraphy. The GPR transects were obtained with a RIS2 equipment from Ingegneria dei
Sistemi using a 200 MHz antenna coupled with a Trimble 5700 GPS positioning system.
Radiograms were corrected for topography before interpretation.

2.1.2. OSL dating
A total of 23 samples (Fig. 1) were dated under the OSL Single Aliquot
Regenerative (SAR) dose protocol (Murray and Wintle, 2000; Wintle and Murray, 2006)
using multigrain aliquots of quartz following standard preparation methods (Wintle, 1997).
Samples were analyzed with Risø TL/OSL readers at the Illinois State Geological Survey
(ISGS; 14 samples) and at the Institute of Geosciences at University of São Paulo (IGc -
USP; 9 samples) with built-in beta source dose rates of 134 mGy/s and 88 mGy/s,
respectively. A pre-heat temperature of 200°C was used for a dose recovery experiment for
given doses of 4, 52 and 140 Gy. The calculated-to-given dose ratio varied from 0.95 to
0.97. Equivalent dose was calculated by exponential fitting of the dose–response data only
when recycling ratios were in the 0.9-1.1 range and recuperation higher than 5%. Feldspar
contamination was appraised repeating the first regeneration dose and using infrared
stimulation before the blue stimulation. Final equivalent dose was determined through the
central age model using at least 16 approved quartz aliquots per sample.
To calculate radiation dose rates mean specific activities (Bq/kg) of 238
U, 232
Th, and
40 K radionucleids, a HPGe detector in an ultralow background shield was used at the IGc-
USP after keeping sealed samples in plastic containers for a 28-day radon equilibration.
123
Conversion factors were used for beta and gamma dose rates calculation (Adamiec and
Aitken, 1998). Cosmic dose rate was evaluated from depth below surface of the sampling
point, altitude, longitude, and latitude (Prescott and Stephan, 1982). Water content was
obtained from the total weight and dry weight after drying the sample in an oven for 48 h
at 110°C.
2.1.3. Textural analysis
Bulk sand from all samples were analyzed at the IGc-USP, using a Malvern
Mastersizer 2000 laser diffraction granulometer with a Hydro 2000MU attachment and
built-in ultrasound device. Results were tabulated in 1-phi interval classes and classified
according to Wentworth (1922). Grain-size statistical parameters were calculated using the
method of moments. All bulk samples were analyzed in the optical microscope. Heavy
minerals were analyzed in the very fine sand fraction. They were separated from light
minerals by gravity-settling in bromoform (CHBr3, density of 2.83 to 2.89 g/cm 3 ) and
placed in glass slides using Canada balsam for optical study under the polarizing
microscope. Four hundred non-micaceous transparent heavy mineral grains plus opaque
grains were counted through the ribbon method (Galehouse, 1971). These textural analysis
were undertaken to differentiate sand bodies. Blocks of undisturbed sands were used to
manufacture polished thin petrographic sections by air-drying and subsequent
impregnation with epoxy resin under vacuum to observe grain and coating structures. To
evaluate mineralogical maturity related to weathering and grain coatings, the following
analysis were performed: (1) Reflectance measurements where bulk samples were made
into a slurry with distilled water on a transparent glass slide and let to dry for a day. The
dried slides were then analyzed with a HunterLab MiniScan XE Plus Spectrophotometer at
ISGS for diffuse color reflectance values in the visible spectra (400×10 ?9

2.2. The Boqueirão Lake analyses
2.2.1. Seismic-reflection profiles
Seismic-reflection transects were acquired to assess the water depth, lake sediment
distribution and the morphology of the sediment layers. We focused on five of the 38
transects obtained in a 2006 survey (Zocatelli et al., 2012; Fig. 3), based on location and
image resolution. Three (total of 854 m) and two (total of 374 m) survey lines were
collected in an approximate E-W and N-S orientation, respectively, using a portable
StrataBox Marine Geophysical instrument at wave frequency of 10 kHz (Zocatelli et al.,
2012). Navigation coordinates were appraised by a Garmin GPS device synchronized with
each recorded pulse from the StrataBox files. Data analysis was done with StrataBox
3.0.4.1 software from SyQwest Inc. assuming a combined average propagation speed of
sound in the water and sediments of 1500 m/s.

2.2.2. Sediment core analysis
The sediment core used in this research (BOQ_07_02; Fig. 3) was collected from
Boqueirão Lake (5°14'52.5''S, 35°32'48.2''W, 17 m asl). The 2.85 m long core was
extracted 75 m from the western margin at the IP21 seismic profile using vibracore at 7.5
m water depth (Zocatelli et al., 2012). In the laboratory, the core was cut into 1 cm and 5
cm increments, for 5-160 and 161-285 cm depths, respectively, for the following analyses:
(1) siliceous microfossils, (2) organic carbon and nitrogen content and stable isotope ratios
(3) chronology, and (4) particle size distribution. These analyses were carried out to obtain
sufficient data to assess lake evolution. A chronological framework coupled with siliceous
microfossils analysis is a traditional method to evaluate paleolimnological conditions, as
microfossils are used as bioindicators of water quality (e.g. Fritz et al., 2006), while
geochemical parameters, as organic carbon content, nitrogen, and carbon isotope ratios, are
indicative of paleoproductivity of lakes (Meyers, 2003). Particle size distribution data
helped to evaluate settling and transport mechanisms (Friedman et al., 1992). Samples for
(1) were analyzed at the Geosciences Laboratory of University of Guarulhos, Brazil. One
cm³ of each sample was stored at ~5 °C to avoid decomposition and degradation of
microfossils. Subsequently, organic matter and carbonate were extracted using H2O2 30-35
%, and HCl 37 %, respectively (Battarbee, 1986). Residual samples were cleaned and
diluted in 50 ml distillated water. Coverslips of 24x32 mm received 20 µl of this residue
that was dried and glued to slides with Entelan®. Results were expressed in
microfossils/cm³ of sediment (Stevenson and Rollins, 2006). Ten g of each bulk sample for
(2) were treated overnight with HCl 10 % to eliminate carbonates. Total organic carbon
(TOC), total inorganic carbon (TIC), total nitrogen (TN), and ? 13
C were determined using
a Finnigan Delta V Plus Mass spectrometer coupled with a Costech Elemental Analyser at

3. Results
3.1. Coastal framework
The remote sensing analysis showed that the study area has marked coastal
alongshore variations that respond to geomorphic features, coastline orientation, and
prevailing wave and wind systems. Predominantly, the fluvial flow pathway is diverted by
the action of active coastal dunes (Fig. 4). Also, transient and permanent shallow lakes fed
by small drainages, and low-lying depression marshes are bounded by dune fronts or
depositional lobes (Fig. 4). A conspicuous feature of the study area is the clear morphology
of active and stabilized dunefields (Fig. 3). Even when physically degraded, these dunes
show a SE-NW elongation direction. Their spatial distribution and the various stages of
dune evolution indicate that they were formed in various episodes of sand advancements.
Active dunes comprise foredunes, nebhkas, blowouts, parabolic, and transgressive
dunefields that move up to 5 km inland. Stabilized eolian landforms include vegetated
deflation plains, trailing and precipitation ridges, stabilized parabolic dunes, and
gegenwalles. Dune NW advancement trails or streaks are not discernable farther than 20
km from the coast where they are in part bounded by the sigmoidally-shaped Boqueirão
Lake (Fig. 4). The Boqueirão Lake western margin presents various zones with concave-
shaped encroachments that point to the NW. These features are not detected in the eastern
margin.
3.2. Dune advancement age clusters
OSL dating results are shown in Table 1. The dune advancement episodes were
classified under five OSL age clusters (Tables 1 and 2) that encompass the following
episodes: (a) Substrate (Older than 31.2 ka), (b) Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, 25.7-24.9
ka), (c) Pleistocene/Holocene boundary (15.2-10.1 ka), (d) Mid-Holocene (8.8-6.3 ka), (e)
Late-Holocene (2.4-2.9, 1.0 and, 0.4-0.6 ka), (f) recently stabilized (less than 0.2 ka) and
(g) active. These clusters group various dune activity episodes that share common
geomorphic, sedimentological and geochemical characteristics. Age clusters (c), (e), (f),
127
and (g) are represented by exposed dune advancements detected in the remote sensing
images. Buried outcrops encompass clusters (a), (b) and (d). Dune advancements records
from 79.9 ka to the Early Holocene showed the occurrence of coarser sand and granules
associated with, elemental Fe concentration and the reflectance a* parameter higher than
3613 and 9, respectively (Table 2). Conversely, Mid-Holocene to active sand
advancements did not present any granules, and showed Fe concentration and a* lower
than 1187 ppm and 8, respectively (Table 2). The major mineral in all clusters was quartz
with concentrations higher than 98%. Quartz grains show pervasive grain coatings (Fig. 9a,
b); also the whiteness intensity reflectance parameter L (Table 2), did not show marked
changes over time. Conversely, other attributes varied from older to younger clusters: (1)
stable with minor contribution from other minerals to unstable heavy minerals suites,
respectively, and (2) moderately sorted fine to moderately well-sorted medium sands,
respectively. An eolian sediment transport pattern was inferred from the westernmost,
Mid-Holocene advancement that showed a downwind change in grain size distribution
(Fig. 2).

3.3. The Boqueirão Lake record
The chronostratigraphy of core Boq 07/02 recorded sedimentation process from ~8
to 1 Cal ka (Fig. 6). Diatoms and sponge spicules were the siliceous microfossils
identified. Spicules, mostly fragmented, were identified as megascleres (Demospongiae
Class) due to their straight or slightly curved oxeas, smooth or with eventual expansions
central areas, and with gradually tapering extremities (Fig. 6). Megascleres were registered
from ~6.5 Cal ka in few numbers, at a time of predominant clay deposition, when the
sedimentation rate was 0.28 mm/yr. Their numbers soared after 4.6 Cal ka, reaching a
maximum at ~4.3 Cal ka, when the prevalent Mastogloia smithii var. lacustris diatoms
started to appear. Diatoms were identified as M. smithii var. lacustris because of their
elliptic-lanceolate valves with broadly rounded rostrate apices. Also, these diatoms
showed: raphe straight with a kink near the central area; proximal raphe ends slightly
expanded, deflected in the same direction; and areolate-radiated striae, weakly curved at
the central area, becoming parallel at the apices. The Figure 7 show that changes from
relative wet to dry climate in Rio Grande do Norte (Cruz et al., 2009) coincided with
striking changes in microfossil occurrence and geochemical parameters in the Boqueirão
Lake.These highest density of diatoms occurred just after spicules disappearing ~3.9 Cal
ka. At this time, clay deposition was highly variable, with a downward trend at a time
when sedimentation rate was 2.22 mm/yr. Increasing CN values were observed ~3.9 Cal ka
when CN and diatom peaks arose simultaneously. The CN signal during subsequent ages
was ~18. ? 13
C values were ~ -15‰ 4.6 Cal ka and became ~13‰ depleted 3.9 Cal ka, in an

Grain size distribution showed a predominance of sands (40-95%) from 1.3-2.85 m
while silt and clay were predominant (> 60 %) from 0.3-1.3 m (Fig. 7). Over time, sand
was mainly deposited from ~8.5-4.5 ka, and silt and clay after 4.5 ka (Fig. 7). Seismic
reflection data (Figs. 3) showed a tectonically unperturbed area overlained by a strong
reflection thin layer (up to 1 m). The boundary between these layers is clear and can be
detected throughout the whole basin. Also, diffuse and high amplitude reflections pointed
to acoustic blanking characteristic of free gas. Sediments thickened towards the major
channel, and shoulders showed erosional or depositional features. Gently and steeply
sloping shorelines were found in the western and eastern edges, respectively. The basin
showed a flat bottom in its central area and a maximum depth of 10 m.

4. Discussion
4. 1. Sand incursion episodes
Our results show that the RN coast was subjected to multiple episodes of sand
deposition in the Late Quaternary. The spatial distribution, geomorphic features and the
sedimentological framework suggest a high eolian contribution to these deposits.
Notwithstanding the Holocene sands showed the imprint of eolian transport with the
deposition of medium to fine sand-grained dunes, older deposits were subjected to other
processes that would bring coarser sands with granules. These grain sizes are not typical of
dunes, hence we suggest four hypothesis or a combination of them to explain their
contribution to sand deposits from age clusters (a), (b) and (c): (1) colluvium produced by
mass wasting from the Barreiras or Post-Barreiras Formations. A modern analog of the
colluvium-eolian framework is found in the northern coast of RN in an outcrop located less
than 250 m from the foreshore where sea-facing cliff accumulations of colluvium from the
Barreiras Formation are intermixed with eolian sediments from a sand ramp formed under
the action of onshore winds (Fig. 8), (2) lateritic soils underlying sand advancements.
These soils would provide the laterite and ferricrite granules found in some samples, (3)
sand-sheet accumulations that usually carry a sizable coarsed-grained population (Kocurek
and Nielson, 1986), and finally (4) fluvial sands. Although the Pleistocene sands had more
complex depositional histories, the contribution from eolian deposition must have been
dominant since the grain-size distribution parameters such as mean diameter and sortness
(Table 2), obtained from phi (-1)-10, point to the same mechanism of transport as revealed
by the Holocene sands. Furthermore, the similar mineral assemblage, and heavy minerals
distribution suggest a common provenance over time.

The spatio-temporal signature of Pleistocene eolian sand incursions is detected in
sample sites RF1, RF14, RF16, and RF17 (Figure 9) where unconformities separate
different age clusters. The most conspicuous site is from ref RF16 where LGM sands are
overlained by recent deposits (Fig. 9). We hypothesize that the hiatus between these
records may be related to sand bypass systems, lack of sand availability or multiple cycles
of deposition and erosion, or a combination of all these possibilities. Notwithstanding,
these older layers show an eolian contribution that has been in action from at least the Late
Quaternary. Also, the extent of these past and present dune advancements must have
affected coastal rivers since the geomorphological framework in such a small area suggests
spatio-temporal interplay between fluvial and eolian systems. The interaction between
these systems would depend on the energy of sand incursions and the competence of the
drainage flow. Thus, the response would be from gradual diversion to complete blockage
of river pathways. Advancements of sand dunes on ephemeral and perennial rivers have
been previously reported in many studies (e.g. Bullard and McTainsh, 2003; Loope et al.,
2005; Teller and Lancaster, 1986). However, few contemplate their impact on coastal
settings, with an exception of studies in coastal Namibia (e.g. Al Masrahy and Mountney,
2015; Krapf et al., 2003; Svendsen et al., 2003). These authors report on ephemeral fluvial
systems that block eolian sand encroachments, and on fluvio-eolian interactions controlled
by the size of river catchments in the Skeleton Coast where dunes block ephemeral river
systems on their path to the Atlantic Ocean, respectively. Likewise, we detect these
features in our study area as illustrated by: (1) an active dune encroachment terminated
near an ephemeral river discharge, although the dune might have diverted the river
previously (Fig. 10a). This arrangement suggests considerable river flow competence that
135
would promote diversion over damming by dunes and subsequent advancement of eolian
activity, when saltating sands would be carried by the drainage to the Atlantic Ocean; (2) a
lake formed when stabilized dunes dammed and deranged a river pathway which is the
case of Boqueirão lake (Fig. 4). Moreover, evidence of past fluvio-eolian interplay can be
found in marshes that are clearly bounded by degraded parabolic ridges and depositional
lobes, and in particular, in the Boqueirão Lake that is bounded by stabilized sand dunes,
and the Barreiras Formation on the eastern and western edges, respectively.

4.2. Fluvio-eolian interaction in the Boqueirão Lake formation
The seismic-profile data allowed us to outline the sediment fill in the Boqueirão Lake
into two parts that correlate with core stratigraphy (Figs. 3). The first part encompasses a
thin top layer (<1 m) that shows abundant biogenic gas mixed with modern finely-grained
lake sediments, and the second bottom part is constituted by a predominantly sandy layer
(below 1 m) that thicken toward the center of the lake. We believe that this sandy layer
shares a common history with sands from the Mid-Holocene dune advancements for two
reasons: (1) grain size statistical data show similar moderately sorted medium-to-fine
grains in both environments (Table 2), and (2) the characteristic lake western gently
sloping shoreline. Although this shoreline feature may be explained by the action of waves
136
developed under longer fetch controlled by the SE winds, the various concave edges in the
western margin, that resemble advancing lobes from parabolic dunes, may indicate other
processes related to the evolution of the Boqueirão Lake. It seems reasonable to
hypothesize that the Boqueirão River followed a structural SW-NE trend that was diverted
to the present Boqueirão Lake western edge with the onset of dune advancements when the
river had sufficient flow competence to resist the sand overburden. Over time, progressive
dune desiccation would leave a relatively flat exposed dune-sand terrain that was gradually
flooded during the upstream blockage of the Boqueirão River river pathway by advancing
dunes (Fig. 10a). The gradual flooding is attested by two buried paleochannels identified in
the profile of Figure 3 In addition, the core data show that the substitution from sandy
substrate to lake sediments also took place gradually then parted in a zig-zag fashion from
~5-4.3 ka (Fig. 3), when sand contribution decreased from 92 to a minimum of 11%,
indicating a transition from fluvial to lacustrine environments.
Further evidence of the fluvial-lacustrine transition is supported by sponge spicules
of Class Demospongiae that indicate an environment dominated by a hard substrate
necessary to sponges fixation from 7.1 to 4.3 ka (Fig. 6). These animals are indicators of
well oxygenated riverine waters, because this is a limiting factor for their survival (Frost et
al., 2001; Frost, 2001). The preservation of these sponges is synchronous with increasing
lacustrine deposition and low organic carbon content, as organic matter was not detected
during this period (Fig. 6). This framework suggests a prevalence of fluvial environments
from ~ 7.1-6.5 ka and a transition from fluvial to lacustrine environments from ~ 6.5-4.3 ka
seen in the microfossil record. The ~ 3.9 ka marks the time when sponge spicules where no
longer present in the sedimentary record and the M. smithii var. lacustris diatoms became
dominant. These diatoms usually live in lake margins over submerged macrophytes
(Torgan and Biancamano, 1991; Gaiser et al., 2010). The diatoms bloom from 4.3-3.9 ka
was promoted by an increase in terrestrial organic matter input as shown in higher CN
(Fig. 7). Higher ? 13
C values indicate a major contribution of C4 over C3 plants just before
4.3 ka whereas depleted ? 13
C values after 4.3 ka indicate an increasing contribution of
algae and C3 plants (Fig. 7). Thus, our records suggest that the replacement of sponges by
diatoms indicates a transition from fluvial to lacustrine systems. From 3.9 ka, lower CN
and ? 13
C values indicate a predominance of algal organic matter. Also, low contribution of
clays and organic rich layers suggest lotic water conditions. Studies in paleolimnology
have shown that these geochemical patterns are characteristics of lacustrine systems
137
(Behling et al., 2001; Meyers, 2003). Finally, our data show that diatoms density was
drastically reduced after 2.3 ka, when lake water presented more stable conditions of
organic matter input, as demonstrated by geochemical proxies (Fig. 7).

4.3. Provenance
In our study area, heavy minerals assemblages differ broadly from foreshore and
active dunefields to older deposits sands (Table 2). High contributions from minerals such
as amphibole, hornblende, augite and hyperstene are limited to younger deposits and are
replaced over time in the stabilized dunefields by a suite dominated by zircon with smaller
concentrations of rutile, tourmaline, sillimanite, and kyanite . Weathering and pedogenic
a
b
138
processes that promote changes towards mature heavy minerals assemblages are chiefly
associated with stabilization of coastal dunefields (e.g. Tsoar and Pye, 2008). As an
example, minerals such as hornblende are destroyed, releasing Fe, Mg and Al ions
(Retallack, 2001) that contribute to the formation of clay, and Fe oxide and hydroxides
coatings that rapidly bound to quartz grains (Rusch et al., 2010). Coated quartz grains are
ubiquitous in stabilized sands, and prevalent in the foreshore and active dunefield sands.
This suggests a contribution of reworked sands from the stabilized dunefields to the
younger deposits.
Another weathering-controlled mechanism that supplies sands from active or
previously active dunefields back to the foreshore involves a positive feedback between
fluvial and eolian processes. Most of the fluvial systems in the area are dominated by
seasonally-controlled ephemeral processes. During the wet season, dune migration would
be interrupted by drainages that present competent flows where saltating sands would be
trapped and subsequently flushed to river mouths where ebb and flow currents promote
local sand accretion on the updrift side while interrupting longshore currents and
depositing sand on the downdrift side. The accumulation of these sands would also benefit
from the continuous presence of beach rocks in the nearshore (Bittencourt et al., 2005;
Vital et al., 2006) that would help preventing dispersion of these sands farther than the
nearshore, thus making them readily available to wind entrainment. Conversely, during the
dry season dune advancements would block or divert drainage pathways thus contributing
to changes in the position of river mouths. These Late Quaternary continuous fluvio-eolian
cycles of sediment reworking explains the zoning of dune advancements and fluvial
pathways over the coast, that superimpose on the tectonic framework (e.g. Bezerra et al.,
2001).
4.4. Paleoclimate
The direction of sand transport by winds for the last 15 ka is towards the NW. This
is supported by trails from active and stabilized parabolic dunes younger than ~ 8.8 ka (age
clusters c, d, e, f, and g ; Tables 1 and 2). Although we do not have direct morphological
evidence on the wind regime from dune advancements from 80-15 ka (age clusters a and b;
Tables 1 and 2) because these sands are buried, it is likely that the Late Quaternary was a
period of strong SE trade winds. Intensity of SE trade winds for the past 21 ka was inferred
from sea surface temperature (SST) variations and abundance records of Florisphaera
139
profunda from northwest and southeast Atlantic, and equatorial Atlantic, respectively (Kim
and Schneider, 2003). These authors suggest strong SE trade winds in the LGM and Mid-
to Late-Holocene. Also, SST gradient from the Angola-Bengala front show strong SE
winds in these periods (Kim et al., 2003). Winds are the primary control in dune
stabilization (e.g. Ashkenazy et al., 2012; Tsoar and Blumberg 2002; Tsoar, 2005), and
precipitation usually plays a secondary role, even at rainfall up to 2 m/yr (e.g. Yizhaq et al.
2009; Tsoar et al. 2009; Arens et al. 2004). Usually, the minimum velocity for sand
transport is 5 m/s (e.g. Pye and Tsoar, 2008). Presently, the RN coast shows very strong
winds all year round. Wet and dry seasons register average speeds that are sustained farther
than Lagoa do Boqueirão, of 6 m/s and 9 m/s. It is reasonable to expect that these wind
speeds were enduring in the LGM and Late- to Mid-Holocene. Thus, prevailing high winds
leads to a situation in which the major control on dune advancements in the study area is
no longer wind speed but sediment availability that peaks during the wet season.
A conspicuous record of paleoprecipitation in our study area was the formation of the
Boqueirão Lake coupled with Mid-Holocene dune advancements. The last sand incursion
in the Mid-Holocene at ~6.3 ka would mark the end of the predominantly wet period and
fits well with the onset of the transitional ~ 6.5-4.3 ka from fluvial to lake environment
shown in the microfossil record. The ~ 6.3 ka mark coincides with the Holocene sea level
highstand of 1.3 m in the northern RN state obtained from radiocarbon dating of beach
rocks (Caldas et al., 2006). Highstands usually contribute to sand supply for dune
advancement (e.g. Giannini et al., 2007), though the effect of this low rise may not have
been significant. Finally, our paleoprecipitation record from the Mid-Holocene fits well
with humid periods reconstructed from oxygen isotopic records from a speleothem located
~ 100 km from coastal RN State for the past 26,000 years (Fig. 7; Cruz et al., 2009).
Precipitation in NE Brazil is controlled by the southern position of the Intertropical
Converge Zone (ITCZ). Thus, the Boqueirão Lake record adds new data to the study of the
ITCZ position during the Holocene.
5. Conclusions
In the NE coast of the Rio Grande do Norte State, Brazil, the interplay of fluvial
and eolian interactions provides evidence of paleoenvironmental change. In this region,
strong SE winds throughout the Late Quaternary make sediment supply the major control
in dunefield encroachment. Humid periods promote sediment availability that is
140
transported to regional and local watersheds. These sediments are discharged in the
Atlantic Ocean and transported to the foreshore that ultimately supplies sands to dune
advancements under the action of onshore SE winds. Thus, the key climatic control on
eolian activity is regional precipitation. Dunefield encroachment provides conditions to
either dam or divert river pathways, depending on river flow competence. In turn, rivers
transport sediments that will ultimately feed dunefield advancements. This fluvio-eolian
interaction seems to be working for at least the last 69 ka. This interplay suggests a holistic
perspective in investigating the geomorphic evolution of the RN coast rather than
examining fluvial or eolian processes alone. The chronological association of dune
advancement and the Boqueirão Lake formation in the Mid-Holocene shows close-
coupling fluvial-eolian interactions and provides evidence of higher precipitation in the
8.8-6.3 ka interval that is in agreement with other regional paleoprecipitation data. The last
dune encroachment in the area at ~6.3 ka signals the onset of a dryer period. The dunefield
blockage of the drainage path is synchronous, within dating uncertainties, to gradual
changes from fluvial to lake microfossils found in a Boqueirão Lake core that indicates a
rise in lake water levels in a predominantly dryer climate framework. A corollary of this is
that attempts to associate increased lake water levels to periods of enhanced precipitation
have to be considered with caution. Our study shows that the effects of geological
processes need to be acknowledged. Also, it brings new insight in the use of coastal fluvio-
eolian interplay as a paleoenvironmental archive.

ABSTRACT
Nordeste Brazil (hereafter NEB) is a region directly affected by the Intertropical
Convergence Zone (ITCZ); where hydrological changes remain poorly documented
beyond the instrumental period. Here, we aim to scrutinize them for the last 2,300 years BP
(before present) by applying an innovative approach combining high-resolution records of
the oxygen isotopic ratio (? 18
O) from Trapiá Cave speleothem with the deuterium isotopic
ratio (?D) of C28 n-alkanoic acid from Boqueirão Lake sediments. Our results confirm that
meridional changes in the ITCZ have occurred during the last millennium in the NEB
climate. They indicate strong centennial-scale variability showing, for instance, that the
Medieval Climate Anomaly (MCA) was marked by a dry period, while the Little Ice Age
(LIA) was characterized by relatively wet conditions. In contrast, a dry climate persisted
over region influenced by South America Convergence zone (SACZ) in southern NEB
(sNEB) during most of last millennium. A dry SACZ is expected during periods of
northern ITCZ because of the weaker South America Summer Monsoon (SASM); however
a wet ITCZ during LIA suggest that the dry sNEB was caused by a well-developed
Nordeste Trough related with a southward displacement of SACZ during stronger SAMS.
147
INTRODUCTION
Nordeste is already a semi-arid area and gradual intensification of this conditions
over the last decades has been intensely impacting the local economy and social
development (Marengo et al., 2011). Understanding the recent past hydrological variability
is therefore crucial to determine whether the regional climate remained stable before
human-induced climate changes or, in contrast, experienced rapid and significant changes
in line with known abrupt climatic events.
Present day precipitations at northeast NEB (nNEB) are largely controlled by the
seasonal ITCZ migration, as a result of atmospheric energy balance which moves the ITCZ
to the warmest Hemisphere (Schneider et al., 2014). During the South Hemisphere summer
(December, January and February), humidity from SACZ at low levels is mostly
transported from the Amazon towards the southern NEB (sNEB), contemplating this area
with humidity. Then, the South Atlantic subtropical anticyclone shifts eastward which is
accompanied by a weakening of the southeast trade winds over NEB coast (Chaves and
Cavalcanti, 2001). As a result, Nordeste Trough is displaced over the nNEB, which
prevents the south migration of ITCZ (Figure 01) and lead to the intensification of drought
over nNEB (Hastenrath, 2006; Schneider et al., 2014).
A dry pattern may also occur in sNEB when there is a southward displacement of the
SACZ, which leads low-level flows directed from the Amazon to the south of Brazil. There
is a strengthening and/or westward shift of the South Atlantic anticyclone with an
intensification of the southeast trade winds along the northeast coast (Chaves and
Cavalcanti, 2001).
Maximum precipitation over nNEB occurs when ITCZ is southerly displaced
during South Hemisphere autumn (March, April and May). During this season, Northeast
trade winds become stronger, the SACZ gradually weakens and the Nordeste trough
migrates over the sNEB (Hastenrath, 2006; Polzin and Hastenrath, 2014; Schneider et al.,
2014) (Figure 01). The resulting autumn rainfall over nNEB, when the ITCZ is at its
southernmost position, contributes to ~50% of the total annual precipitation (ref to GNIP-
IAEA). Isotopic values (? 18
O and ?D) of these ITCZ rainfalls are more negative than
during other seasons (Figure 1 S – supplementary material) (Bowen and Revenaugh, 2003;
Bowen, 2015; GNIP-IAEA). Mainly affected by the amount effect, the isotopic values are
inversely proportional to the relative changes in precipitation amount, similarly to other
tropical regions (Craig, 1961; Risi et al., 2008; Cruz et al., 2009).
148

2001), (5) Pumacocha Lake (Bird et al., 2011), (6) Palestina Cave (Apaestégui et al.,
2014).
Low-resolution studies yielded so far that NEB climate was overall dry during the
Late Holocene (i.e. the last 5,000 years BP) (e.g. Sifeddine et al., 2003; Cruz et al., 2009).
The only high-resolution record available report overall dry conditions during the last
millennia in NEB, punctuated by brief wet events (Novello et al., 2012). The Little Ice Age
(~550-100 years BP) - a cold Northern Hemisphere climatic phase – was characterized by
weak rainfalls influenced by SACZ in NEB (Novello et al., 2012), which strongly contrasts
with the humid conditions documented in other tropical areas (Bird et al., 2011; Vuille et
al., 2012; Apaéstegui et al., 2014). Comparatively, the MCA (~1000-700 years BP) was
marked by enhanced dryness in sNEB (Novello et al., 2012) in line with previous studies
in tropical regions (Shanahan et al., 2009; Bird et al., 2011; Vuille et al., 2012; Apaéstegui
et al., 2014). Hence, the NEB seems to be mostly dry whatever past climate changes in the
149
SASM domain over the continent. However, the relationship between ITCZ and SACZ is
still not well established in Nordeste for the last millenium.
The Atlantic Multi-decadal Oscillation (AMO) forcing has been invoked to explain
the centennial scale variability in NEB (Novello et al., 2012), while its influence remains
unclear. Indeed, colder (warmer) sea surface temperatures (SST) in the Equatorial North
Atlantic strengthened (weakened) the AMO which, in turn, led to a southward (northward)
ITCZ displacement and promoted humidity transport from the warm South Atlantic Ocean
to NEB (Novello et al., 2012), in a similar manner than during the seasonal timescale
(Schneider et al., 2014). However, during enhanced AMO periods (e.g. the LIA), it has not
been found a linear response in the ITCZ position and precipitation rates in sNEB,
contrasting with most of the present day regions affected by the ITCZ, as found for
instance in paleodata from Western Africa (Shanahan et al., 2009).
Present day climatology indicates that the Nordeste Trough can also be responsible
for large-scale subsidence and aridity over sNEB during periods of enhanced SACZ (south
Hemisphere summer), suggesting a long-term continentally antiphased system that follow
changes in insolation (Cruz et al., 2009; Novello et al., 2012). Yet, it remains elusive
whether these changes in the upper-tropospheric topography and divergence, and hence of
vertical motion over the Atlantic during SASM´s precipitation events leads to a significant
change in precipitation at a secular to millennial time scale during last millennium in the
nNEB, a region more directly affected by ITCZ position (Hastenrath, 2006; Schneider et
al., 2014).
The lack of records in Nordeste is partly explained by the semi-arid conditions that
reduce the number of paleoarchives and high time resolution. In order to fill this gap, we
aim to reconstruct past regional hydrology in NEB for the last 2,300 yrs BP by using two
new complementary records. We used a speleothem section collected at the Trapiá Cave
(TRA) that hosts active stalagmite, which is extremely rare for the area (Bento et al.,
2011), combined to a very well-dated lake sediment core at lower resolution from the
Boqueirão Lake (BL) (Figure 01). In order to monitor past hydrological changes, we used
the oxygen isotopes (? 18
O) in speleothems and deuterium isotopes (?D) of n-alkanoic acids
from lake sediments. These proxies, relatively well constrained (Risi et al., 2008; Cruz et
al., 2009), are closely related to hydrological cycles.
150
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Speleothem TRA7 (2,330m long and ~5cm diameter) was collected in Trapiá Cave
(Rio Grande do Norte State, Brazil) located at 5°33’45.43”S; 37°37’15.92"W, 90 km from
the Atlantic coast, and ~ 50 m above sea level. Twelve ages were obtained based on U -Th
geochronology at the Minnesota Isotope Laboratory, University of Minnesota, using an
inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) technique, according to Cheng et
al. (2013), and the age model was constructed by linear interpolation. The speleothem
TRA7 provides a record of the last 5000 years. In this study we focus on the last ca. two
millenia. (Figure 2S and Table 1S - Supplementary material). Oxygen isotopes were
analyzed on 563 samples with an online automated carbonate preparation system linked to
a Thermo Finnigan Delta Plus Advantage mass spectrometer at the Laboratório de
Isótopos Estáveis, Instituto de Geociências, São Paulo University. ? 18
O are reported in the
delta notation relative to the Vienna Pee Dee Belemnite (VPDB). Reproducibility of
standard materials is 0.06‰ for ? 18
O and samples error propagation less than 0.25‰.
Core Boq 09/01 (0.9 m long) was retrieved from Boqueirão Lake (Rio Grande do
Norte State, Brazil), located at 5°14?42.51?S; 35°32?40.80?W, 235 km east from the Trapiá
Cave and 8 km from Atlantic coast. Boqueirão is an open lake ~ 6 km long, ~ 350 m
width, ~ 30 m above sea level, with a maximum water depth of 10 m. The age model,
based on 14
C AMS dates on bulk organic matter, has been published in Viana et al. (2014).
Samples were prepared and quantified at LOCEAN-UPMC (Laboratoire d’Océanographie
et du Climat, Expérimentations et Approches Numériques – Université Pierre et Marie
Curie, Paris).
Lipids from 90 sediment samples of the Boq 09/01 core were extracted by
ultrasonication with a DCM/MeOH (3:1) solvent mixture. After saponification of the
resulting total lipid extracts with 4M KOH/MeOH, removal of the neutral fraction with
hexane and acidification of the residue, the acid fraction was recovered with hexane/ethyl
acetate (9:1), methylated using BF3 and further purified by column chromatography over
silica gel and elution with DCM:hexane (2:1). Fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) were
analysed on an Agilent 6890N gas chromatograph (GC) using flame ionisation detection
(FID). Quantification of compounds was performed by peak area integration in FID
chromatogramms relative to the internal standard 5?-cholenic acid added prior to
extraction. In order to confirm compounds identification selected samples were analysed
by GC-MS on an Agilent 7890 GC coupled to an Agilent 5975 mass selective detector.
151
Isotope analyses were performed at MARUM (Center for Marine Environmental
Sciences) - University of Bremen. Compound-specific deuterium isotope analyses were
performed on a Thermo Trace GC coupled to a Thermo Fisher Scientific MAT 253 IRM-
MS. Measurements were calibrated against 2 H reference gas with known isotopic
composition and H3+ factor monitored daily. Mass balance corrections were made for the
added methyl group. ?D values are reported in permil (‰) relative to the Vienna Standard
Mean Ocean Water (VSMOW) standard. Error propagation is less than 4‰ for ?D.
RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
The ? 18
O values of Trapiá Cave speleothem TRA7 (? 18
OTRA7) vary between -0.7 and
-5.7‰, with an average of -2.8 ‰ over the last 2,300 yr BP (Figure 02). This range is also
observed from 2,300 to 1,500 yr BP (355 yr BC to 440 yr AD), when ? 18
OTRA7 data tends
to more depleted values. Between 1,700 and 1,500 yr BP (250 to 440 yr AD) is recorded
the most negative values, from -5.7 to -3.5 ‰, followed by a period of enrichment at
around 5 ‰ from 1,500 to 1,000 yr BP (440 to 925 yr AD), before a hiatus in the
speleothem record between 1,000 and 615 yr BP (925 and 1,330 yr AD). From 600 to 440
yr BP (1,330 to 1510 yr AD), the ? 18
OTRA7 values are around -1.4 ‰ and abruptly
decreased around 440 yr BP, and around 360 yr BP ? 18
OTRA7 until reaching ~ -4,0 ‰.
Between 360 to 200 yr BP (1,590 to 1,750 yr AD), the ? 18
OTRA7 values are around -3.1 ‰.
After 200 yr BP, the most recent ? 18
OTRA7 values seem to be more stable with values
around -3.4 ‰, increasing in the most recent ages.
A similar curve structure found in ? 18
OTRA7 is observed for Boqueirão Lake ?DC28
values. ?DC28 values vary from -140 to -100 ‰ with a mean around -121 ‰ (Figure 02).
From 2,300 to 1,460 yr BP (355 to 490 yr AD), ?DC28 values vary from -140 to -127 ‰,
and the average is - 132 ‰, and the most deplete value is -140‰ around 1,630 yr BP.
There is an abrupt enrichment in ?DC28 data after 1,460 yr BP. During the period from 1460
to 480 yr BP (490 to 1,470 yr AD) ?DC28 values vary from -125 to -100‰, with values
around -114 ‰ and maximum values around -100 ‰ around 680 yr BP. After 480 yr BP
until the Recent, ?DC28 values deplete from -121 to -140 ‰, with values around -130 ‰.
The ?DC28 data show a smaller resolution, an average of ~25 years/samples (Viana et
al., 2014), compared to ~4 years/samples for speleothems. The larger range of ?DC28
(~40‰) compared with ? 18
OTRA7 (~6‰) may be related to the enrichment of ?DC28 caused
by the intense evapotranspiration in arid environments (Tuthorn et al, 2015), and other
152
physiological fractionation processes during lipids production (Sachse et al., 2012).
Concerning lipid origin, long chains are usually produced by higher plants but different
species produce molecules with a range of chains with different number of carbons,
although these molecules use to record the same trends for isotopic analyses (Jacob et al.,
2007; Leduc et al., 2013). Besides that, the combination of ?D and ? 18
O curves is quite
similar, so that it shows that the fractionation processes do not affect the main fluctuation
in ?DC28 and therefore its suitability for reconstructing paleoprecipitation.
The relationship among ? 18
O, ?D and precipitations rates of the present day rainfalls
indicates that higher precipitation rates are related to lower values of oxygen and
deuterium isotopes (Figure 01 S – Supplementary Material), as expected from the
amount effect (Craig, 1961; Risi et al., 2008). Besides that, the distance and the altitude of
the study areas from the ocean are not significative to be affected by fractionation caused
by continental and altitude effect. These relationships support the correlation of isotopes
paleorecords and precipitation, which is interpreted to be inversely proportional to the
relative changes in precipitation amount, like in other tropical regions (Risi et al., 2008;
Cruz et al., 2009), referred here as humid or dry period.
The average of ? 18
OTRA7 is equivalent to the modern mean seasonal precipitation
? 18
O signal for autumn (MAM) rains registered next to the Urubu Cave (GNIP-IAEA)
(Figure 01 S – Supplementary Material), suggesting that 18
OTRA7 may represent
predominantly the ITCZ signal. Considering this interpretation for water isotopes, the
lowest values of isotopes data from NEB are recorded for the period from 1,700 to 1,500 yr
BP (250 to 440 yr AD) and interpreted to reflect the wettest phase registered since 2,300 yr
BP. The same interpretation is applied to the period between 440 to 50 yr BP (1,580 to
1,900 yr AD) where are also registered low values of ? 18
OTRA7 and ?DC28. Our isotopic data
fit very well with Boqueirão Lake level reconstruction for the last 2,300 yr, which was
based on diatoms transfer function (Viana et al., 2014) (Figure 03S – Supplementary
Material). However, this data are negatively correlated with our isotopic data from
Boqueirão Lake and Trápia Cave, suggesting an opposite interpretation. The past high
levels of Boqueirão Lake and other paleolimnological data (Zocatelli et al., 2012; Viana et
al., 2014) are not a primary result of precipitation rates but related with environmental
changes linked to precipitation and dunes migration that affect the lake morphology (Zular
et al., unpublished). This is an important issue to give more attention, since not only
paleolimnological data should be used to infer precipitation rates.

The highest values of ? 18
OTRA7 and the hiatus in the speleothem between 1,000 and
600 yr BP, complemented by the most enriched values ?DC28 data indicate extremely dry
conditions in NEB, causing the interruption in speleothem precipitation. These dry
154
conditions may be the result of a North displacement of ITCZ, and inversely, wet
conditions between 360 and 50 yr BP, from a South displacement of ITCZ. These periods
may be correlated to MCA and LIA, respectively. Our data present a positive correlation
with reconstructions of decadal surface temperature of North Atlantic (AMO) that
determined the ITCZ position. These climatic events are supposed to be forced by
variations in Sea Surface Temperatures (SST), linked to the Atlantic Multidecal Oscillation
(AMO), described as higher (lower) in North Atlantic during the MCA (LIA) (Sicre et al.,
2008; Mann et al., 2009) (Figure 02).
Comparing this process with present day process, the main position of ITCZ is
controlled by the gradient of SST between North and South Hemisphere, resulted from an
atmospheric energy balance, transporting the ITCZ toward the warmest area (Hastenrath,
2006; Schneider et al., 2014). During North Hemisphere summer (winter), SST increases
(decreases) and ITCZ become northerly (southerly) displaced transporting humidity from
Atlantic Ocean to North America (South America), leading to dry (wet) conditions in
nNEB. As our data demonstrated, this process was active during the MCA and LIA.
In order to get a meridional ITCZ control, when we compare our data with northern
South America data from Cariaco Basin, we find that during the MCA (LIA) higher
(lower) percentages of Ti in marine core indicate intense (low) precipitations (Haug et al.,
2001). This negative correlation with our data from nNEB and positive correlation with
AMO (Figure 02) mark an antiphased system between Hemispheres as suggested by Cruz
et al. (2009) during a meridional movement of ITCZ.
In agreement with a dry period in nNEB, oxygen isotopes data from Iraquara records,
sNEB (~12ºS), show enriched values that indicate dry conditions during the MCA
(Novello et al., 2012) (Figure 02), as supported by other data from Andes (Apaéstegui et
al., 2014; Vuille et al., 2012; Bird et al., 2011) (Figure 04 S – Supplementary material).
During these dry events, these areas were under influence of weak SASM that seems to be
strongly correlated to the ITCZ North position (Schneider et al., 2014). SASM was also
supposed to be controlled by the AMO (Chiessi et al., 2009; Strikis et al., 2011; Novello et
al., 2012) and comparison with our data and reconstructed AMO (Mann et al., 2009)
confirms that their positive values are in accordance with dry conditions in both nNEB and
sNEB during the MCA (Figure 02).
AMO is also supposed to be linked with ITCZ migration over West Africa, since the
seasonal precipitation in this region is influenced by ITCZ meridional movements
155
(Shanahan et al., 2009). Bosumtwi Lake in Africa is under ITCZ influence and Si intensity
data obtained from its sediments is positively correlated with isotopic data from Trapiá
Cave and Boqueirão Lake in NEB (Figure 04S). This correlation indicates that drought
(wet) conditions were predominant in West Africa and nNEB during the MCA (LIA), both
caused by the north (south) displacement of the ITCZ.
Persistent dry climate is found at sNEB during the LIA, as recorded by enriched ? 18
O
values of speleothems (Novello et al., 2012), while our data report wet climate at nNEB
(Figure 02). These opposite conditions in sNEB and nNEB occurred during a period of
enhanced SASM registered in Andes region (Apaéstegui et al., 2014; Vuille et al., 2012;
Bird et al., 2011) that is in agreement with a southern displacement of ITCZ registered by
our data and Cariaco Basin.
An intensification of Nordeste Trough during an enhanced SASM was invoked to
explain sNEB dryness (Novello et al., 2012), and may also be associated with a southward
displacement of SACZ and a westward displacement of the Bolivian High during summer
periods (Chaves and Calvalcanti, 2001), still allowing a southern ITCZ during autumn
period and wet nNEB during the LIA.
These records associated with our data indicate that in South America, the LIA was a
wet period because of an enhanced SASM and a south displacement of ITCZ, inducing wet
conditions ~5° S (nNEB), with a southward displacement of SACZ and intensification of
Northeast Trough, which caused dryness ~ 12° S (sNEB). Different climatic conditions
between Trapiá Cave/Boqueirão Lake (nNEB) and Iraquara records (sNEB) suggest that
SASM did not affect the cave-lake since 2,300 yr BP, and then the isotopic records of our
study represent purely ITCZ precipitation.
The periods of climatic conditions changes in NEB seems to be larger than that
described for Cariaco Basin (Haug et al., 2001) and AMO (Mann et al., 2009) (Figure 02).
Differences in archives, proxies and resolution may result in these variations, but we also
have to considerate that ITCZ is not the only factor influencing dryness in NEB. An
intensification of Northeast Through during increasing SASM rainfall may reduce
precipitation over NEB (Cruz et al., 2009; Novello et al., 2012) and indications of
increasing SASM just after the MCA are registered in low values of ? 18
O in Iraquara
records-NEB, lower values of AMO and other data from Andes region (Figure 04S –
Supplementary material). Further data and model studies are however needed in order to
156
depict a more detailed picture of the hydrological conditions and the related forcing
mechanisms in NEB over the last millennia.

ABSTRACT
Clastic sediment infilling and organic matter deposition in cave conduits can be closely
related to local environmental conditions such as hydrology, soil formation/erosion which
could be influenced by changes in precipitation or type of vegetation cover above the cave.
In this study the clastic sediment and bat guano sequences dated by OSL and radiocarbon
techniques were used to define periods were the main cave gallery of Urubu were
hydrologic active and abandoned during Holocene. This data was combined with the
carbon and oxygen isotope records of speleothems from nearby caves to in order to
reconstruct the regional environment history and ecological settings evolving vegetation
and bats. The age of terrigenous sediments originated from erosion of soil were deposited
in Urubu Cave when the underground river was active at least from ~7,300 yr BP until
~44400 cal yr BP. which is consistent with more humid conditions indicated by the lowest
values of ?18O of speleothem. The end of clastic deposition defined by charcoal
fragments dated around ~4,200 cal yr BP is synchronous with an abruptly increase in
?18O that end of speleothem deposition in the cave other vegetation proxies. After ~2,700
cal yr BP there is no more sediments deposition, due to dry conditions related to the
reduction of phreatic zone. These environmental characteristics permit the preservation of
guano. A hiatus in the speleothem from Trapiá Cave indicate very dry conditions between
1,000 and 600 yr ago, this is registered immediately by a decline in bat population and a
completely absence of bats after 600 yr ago. This time delay in bat population corresponds
to the time of decline in primary production, as a response to climate change that affected
167
food source of bats. Wetter conditions start to increase from ~400 yr BP to the Recent, but
bat guano restarts accumulation in ~200 yr BP, when wetter conditions became more
stable, after a time to reconstitution of vegetation in the region.
Key-words: bat-guano, paleoclimate changes, Northeast Brazil
INTRODUCTION
Diverse alternatives of paleoarchives have been studied around the world, since
different climate and environmental conditions produce various deposits as a result of
weathering actions. Specially in underground, caves are very good sites for sediment
accumulation and spelogenesis. Sediments are remobilized from surface and transported to
drainages, usually entering the cave transported by fluviokarst, and may display a
paleohydrological cycle, as well as studies about spelothems (Auler et al., 2009;
Arriolabengoa et al., 2015).
After deposition inside the caves, these sediments and spelothems are protected
from surficial weathering process and preserves information about their history. Achieving
the potential of cave deposits as archives of past environmental changes requires a better
understanding of the erosion, transport and deposition of inside caves (González-Lemos et
al., 2015).
These processes that affect the surface also interfere the isotopic signal of
carbonates precipitated in caves. Usually oxygen isotopes are the most expected study
concerning paleoclimate and speleothems, because isotopic fractionation are very well
understood when compared with carbon isotopes (Fairchild et al., 2006; Fairchild and
Baker, 2012). Regarding paleoenvironmental changes, carbon isotope signals are mostly
related to changes of vegetation interfering on the soil isotopic signal, although these signal
are not directly correlated to vegetation (Frisia & Borsato, 2010; Wong & Breecker, 2015).
Besides speleothems and sediments preserved in caves, diverse organic
accumulations are preserved, as guano produced by birds or bats, fecal pellets of mammals,
packrat middens, and others, and they seems to be good elements to provide information
from past environment and regional climate (Plummer et al., 1997; Johnston et al., 2010;
Onac et al., 2014).
Many paleoclimate studies use speleothems as archives, they reflect changes related
to paleohydrology but they can not explain the impacts produced by hydrological cycles
changes in ecological features. Since bats are good bioindicators, guano produced by them
168
may act as well (Jones et al., 2009; Wurster et al., 2015), given us important environmental
and ecological information of past populations (Ayliffe, 2010).
In Northeast Brazil (NEB) arid to semi-arid climatic conditions prevent the
accumulation of the most usual records, as speleothems, lakes, turfs, etc. But in Urubu
Cave, at Rio Grande do Norte, there are a sequence of terrigenous deposit and guano
accumulation that we studied in terms of age and stratigraphic conditions to reconstruct the
environmental history in the surroundings of Urubu Cave and ecological settings evolving
vegetation and bats. Changes observed in cave sediments are compared with isotopic data
from speleothems from the same region to try to explain how paleohydrological changes
were correlated with process of cave sedimentation.
REGIONAL SETTINGS
Urubu Cave
Regional karst at Felipe Guerra, Rio Grande do Norte, is developed in Cretaceous
carbonates from Apodi Group, Jandaíra Formation, described as calcarenite and bioclastic
calcilutites (Angelim et al., 2006). In Felipe Guerra, most part of the cave entrances is
located at locally known as Lajedos that are the highest areas of denudation of carbonate
rocks. Here we present data from Rainha Cave, Trapiá Cave, and in special data from
Urubu Cave, which is located at 5°33’45.43”S and 37°37’15.92"W (Figure 1).
The Urubu Cave has around 30 m of linear extension and has two major salons
connected by two channels, in two levels, one channel over the other. The first salon and
the channel in a lower level are partially filled with terrigenous sediments, and the
sediments in the salon are covered with guano. Terrigenous deposit in the first salon is
partially eroded (section A in Figure 2b), forming a natural trench of 217 cm. The channel
was completely filled with terrigenous sediments and is also partially eroded. From the
base, it has 177 cm of compacted orange carbonate clay, interrupted at 85 cm from the top
by a layer of orange clay with charcoal fragments and carbonate crusts. This terrigenous
deposit is covered with 40 cm of guano.
The upper channel and the last salon are partially filled with bat guano (Figure 1). In
the salon, the guano pille lean in the cave wall, forming a half pille of around 3m from the
top (section H in Figure 2a). Probably under the guano there are terrigenous sediments that

MATERIALS AND METHODS
Sediments in the first salon of the cave, collected in the section A indicated in
Figure 2, were collected using PVC tubes to obtain samples without light incidence at 90
(B6C) and 185 (B6D) cm and analyzed using OSL method in the Risø reader at Federal
University of São Paulo. In this profile charcoal fragments (Cave-1-85) were collected at
85 cm for AMS analyses. The depths 53, 70, 90 and 185 cm, and the top of the sequence
were sampled for granulometry analyzes and stored in plastic bags. Granulometry analyses
of these samples were performed at Laboratory of Sedimentology of Geoscience Institute
of University of São Paulo in a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser diffraction granulometer
with a Hydro 2000MU attachment and built-in ultrasound device. Results were tabulated in
1-phi interval classes and classified according to Wentworth (1922). Grain-size statistical
parameters were calculated using the method of moments.
To avoid deformation and compaction of guano samples, we made a trench of
around 1mx1m and the maximum depth of guano accumulation. This procedure was made
for five different guano profiles, from the top of the pille to the base in sequence named
B1, B2, B3, B4 and B5, with 48, 112, 56, 150 and 100 cm of depth, respectively. The
samples B1-46-48, B2-0-2, B2-96-98, B2-110-112, B3-54-56 and B5-70-72 (profile name
+ depth in cm) were collected and analyzed following the standard procedure for liquid
scintillation counting (Pessenda and Camargo, 1991). They were chemically treated
according to Pessenda et al. (1996) and Pessenda et al. (2010) and carbon analysis carried
out at the CENA Radiocarbon Laboratory (Piracicaba, Brazil).
We also made two undeformed sampling using U-channels for B1 and B4, named
B*1 and B*4, with 86 and 190 cm depth. X-ray technique and digital camera were used to
obtain images of these guano profiles.
Six samples from profile B*1 (12, 24, 36, 62, 82 and 94 cm), eight samples from
B*4 (12, 28, 44, 58, 76, 96, 120 and 148 cm), all of them named as profile name + interval
in cm, and charcoal sample (Cave-1-85) were collected and analyzed using the accelerator
mass spectrometry (AMS) technique at Radiocarbon Dating Laboratory from University of
Illinois (Urbana-Champaign-USA).
All ages are reported as Before Present (Before AD 1950). OSl ages are presented
in kyr and radiocarbon ages are reported as 14C yr BP and normalized to ?13C of around
?25‰ VPDB, according to the samples ?13C signal. They were calibrated using Calib 7.1
software and SHcal13 model curve (Hogg et al., 2013) and reported as cal yr BP (2?). Age
172
models for guano profiles were produced using calibrated ages and simple linear
regression.
Oxygen isotopes and U/Th ages from speleothem RN1 and RN4 from Rainha Cave,
was published by Cruz et al. (2009) and here we present its ?13C data , we also present ?13C
data for speleothem TRA7, which its oxygen isotopes and U/Th ages are described by
Utida et al. (unpublished). For each measurement, around 200µg of powder was drilled
from the sample and analyzed with an on-line, automated, carbonate preparation system
linked to a Finnigan Delta XL ratio mass spectrometer at the University of Massachusetts
for RN1 and RN4 speleothems, and to a Finnigan Delta Plus Advantage at the University
of São Paulo for TRA7. Carbon isotope ratios are referred as permil deviation from the
VPDB standard.
RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
Urubu Cave
Samples B6C and B6D consist of quartz grains that have good luminescence signal.
Recycling rate values are 0.96-1.09 and 0.94-1.06 for B6C and B6D samples, respectively,
attesting the reliability of the SAR method (Single Aliquot Regenerative dose) to obtain
burial ages of these samples. Results of the analysis of equivalent dose, dose rates and ages
are shown in Table 1.
OSL ages from terrigenous sediment samples from 185 and 90 cm resulted in 7,415
± 545 and 5,114 ± 363 yr, respectively, corresponding to a sedimentary deposition between
7,350 and 5,050 yr BP (Table 1). This period is followed by charcoal AMS age of 3,880 ±
20 14C yr BP, or 4,233 cal yr BP.
Granulometry of terrigenous sediments is predominantly silt from 90 to 53 cm,
varying from 51 to 54%, sands represent less than 20%. The base of the deposit, 185 cm,
has equal percentages of silt and clay, ~35%. Guano from the top of this sequence is
composed of 43 and 32% of silt and clay, respectively.
Guano ages vary from 2,740 cal yr BP to the Recent (Table 1), considering the
most basal sample (B5-70-72) and the top of guano accumulation (B2-0-2). B*1 profile is
registered from 1,726 cal yr BP, approximately at the same time of B*4, ~1640 cal yr BP.
The most new ages are between 37 and 89 cal yr BP for 12 cm in both B*4 and B*1
profile, suggesting that the top of the sequences cover the Recent, as registered in B2-0-2.
173
Carbon ages for both profiles B*1 and B*4 show very confident ages with
acceptable errors between 15 and 20 years, only for B5 were registered 30 years of error.
No significant inversions were detected, in B*4 they are overlapped by the errors.
The X-ray image of B*1 shows that it has overlaid sediments that indicate it is
positioned on the center of the guano pille (Figure 3). B*1 profile has a continuous
accumulation rate of 0.06 cm/year from ~1,726 to ~677 yr BP. From ~677 to ~213 yr BP
there is not deposition of guano, observed in the X-ray image as a transition between two
different colors in guano (Figure 3). Guano accumulation rate increases more than twice
(0.14 cm/year) from ~213 yr BP to the Recent and X-ray image shows significant change
in guano color, compared with the anterior period.
Images of B*4 profile shows guano sediments overlaid and slopping, confirming its
position dislocated in relation to the center of the pille and the slopping of guano from the
top may be the cause of the age inversions (Figure 3). Accumulation rate is 0.65 cm/year
from ~1,749 to 1,593 yr BP and reduces to 0.06 cm/year from 1,593 to 1,035 yr BP. Age
model of B*4 indicates a presence of an hiatus between 1,035 and 158 yr BP, but in
images it is not clear where it is positioned. After 158 yr BP guano accumulation restarts in
a rate of 0.3 cm/year.
Rainha and Trapiá Cave
The combination of carbon isotopes obtained for Rainha Cave, speleothems RN1
and RN4, cover from 25 to 4 ky BP, with an hiatus between ~ 13,000 and 16,500 yr BP
(Figure 4). ?13C values from 25,000 to 17,000 yr BP become depleted in around 5‰, from
-7 to -12‰. After the hiatus, ?13C values are stable in around -10‰ until 5,000 yr BP,
when abruptly enrich, reaching 1.4‰. We were able to complement ?13C data until the
Recent using data from the speleothem TRA7, from Trapiá Cave, which indicate enriched
values around -3.3‰ for the last 5,000 yr BP.

Paleoenvironmental and paleoecological interpretation
The period of higher deposition of terrigenous sediments in Urubu Cave occur from
7,500 to 5,000 yr BP, and correspond to the maximum humidity since 25,000 yr BP,
according to depleted ?18O values of speleothems from RN during a low solar insolation on
orbital time scales (Cruz et al., 2009) (Figure 4), suggesting a relationship between its
formation and precipitation amount.
The origin of sediment caves in Brazil usually is associated with sediment input
from a runoff or from a doline, because their entrances are in a lower portion of slopes or
dolines (Auler et al., 2009). Similar position of entrances and dolines are observed in
Felipe Guerra’s Caves that could contribute to sediment input to the cave conducts but at
the Urubu Cave the predominance of silt in terrigenous sediments suggest a calmer
environment of deposition. Another possibility of sediment input is the upward of phreatic
zone that may transport sediments and deposit them inside the cave. Even with high flow
velocities it produces a deposit of clay, resulted from residues of the weathered limestone
(Sasowsky, 2007).
The hypothesis of upward of phreatic zones is supported by an increase in
pluviosity at Rio Grande do Norte (Figure 4), and may explain the absence of speleothems
in Urubu Cave, related to the presence of high phreatic zone that filled at least the lower
conducts and salons, unable a development of a carbonate precipitation system. The
absence of spelothems in the sallons in the upper level may be related to drip waters with
high pH, that were not saturated with bicarbonates dissolved from rocks.
This indicates that humid conditions favoured surface wash and consequently a
perhaps a reduction of vegetation cover, allowing the erosion of soils, and their transport
and sedimentation along the environments to the cave (Arriolabengoa et al., 2015).
This terrigenous deposit is marked by an abrupt dry event ~ 4,200 cal yr BP,
indicated by charcoal fragment, and also by an abrupt enrichment of ?18O values (Figure
4). Carbonate crusts deposited with charcoal fragments may indicate a transition between
phreatic to vadose conditions, when they were precipitated (Sasowsky, 2007), supporting
the idea of less humid conditions.
The deposition of terrigenous in this interval may be related to a transitional period
from higher to less precipitation, when there was a slowly reduction on phreatic level until
an absence of water over the deposits.
177
A compact deposit and an absence of any deposition marks in Urubu Cave is an
evidence of deposition under low currents, slackwater (Herman et al., 2012), and not
strong changes in water flow since ~7,000 yr BP. Otherwise, marks such as ripples,
crescent marks, and rill marks would be evidence of water flow and flow direction,
characterizing intense fluviokarst currents, but the presence of pools could be an
environment of low current deposition (González-Lemos et al., 2015), since the deposit
analyzed is in the upper salon. However, a natural trench exposed the sediments in Urubu
Cave was produced at some moment during the transitional period, when rains may favour
runoff in the slopes and sediment incisions inside the caves, because the water flow was
not enough to transport sediments into the cave (Auler et al., 2009; Farrant & Smart,
2011).
This transition is recorded by an enrichment of ~3‰ in ?18O, indicating an increase
in dry conditions, and of more than 10‰ in ?13C (Figure 4). The most depleted values of
?13C recorded in speleothems from RN, ~-10‰, were influenced predominantly by the
depleted signal of carbon sources present in soil over carbonate rocks.
During water percolation in soil the main fractionation process occur for oxygen
and carbon isotopes during the hydrolysis reaction with carbonic gas and/or dissolved
inorganic carbon available in soil. The soil isotopic signal is predominantly negative and
will depends mainly on soil physical properties, microbial community, deep C3 roots, roots
respiration and vegetation predomince (C3 or C4) given to speleothem ?13C a negative
signal. While dissolution reaction is predominant during rock percolation with typical
values of ?18O are ~0 ‰ (Fairchild and Baker, 2012; Wong & Breecker, 2015).
During this transition ?13C data enrich, reaching 0‰, when they recorded the
predominance of rock carbonates over soils. This change in speleothem ?13C signal is
related to an abrupt environmental change over the cave that removed the soil above, as
observed in the recent conditions (Figure 1).
An abrupt transition between humid and dry conditions could have affected the
vegetation in NEB and have exposed the soils over Urubu Cave, as indicated by charcoal
age ~ 4,200 cal yr BP. As a result of less covering of soil by vegetation, more intense was
the erosional process that removed the remaining soil, given a chance to predominate ?13C
carbonate rock signal in speleothems.
