Over terrigenous deposition, there is guano preservation dated ~2,600 yr BP. The
absence of water inside the cave allowed the preservation of guano, and enriched values of
?18O confirms dryer conditions.
Guano’s ages indicate that deposition was continuous from 1,726 to 1,035 yr BP
(Figure 3) during a period of increasing dry conditions (Utida et al. unpublished). Age’s
comparison between B*4 and B*1 profiles show that from 1,035 to 677 yr BP there was a
reduction in bat roost, represented by deposition only in B*1 profile, the top of the pille
(Figure 3). A hypothesis to explain the hiatus in guano accumulation may be related to
climate change, disease or some other catastrophe that had affected the colony (Maher,
2006; Batina and Reese, 2011). Nowadays there are no migratory bat species in Brazil
(Reis et al., 2007), which unfavour this hypothesis to explain guano hiatus.
The beginning of bats population decline coincides with a hiatus in speleothem
deposition that indicates the driest conditions in the last 2,000 yr BP (Figure 3), and a
complete hiatus in guano profiles is registered from 677 to 212 yr BP.
The bat colony colapsed in Urubu Cave represents a series of ecological response to
very dry conditions, suggesting that they are good bioindicators. They have a very rich
trophic diversity, representing the large range of food source, indicating that plant and
insects populations were also affected by climate changes. Moreover, their slow
reproductive rates are good to monitoring long term changes, in which short temporal
changes are not registered (Jones et al., 2009), favoring their use in paleontological studies.
Before the begging of hiatus in bat guano accumulation a decline in pollen index from
Serra do Maranguape indicate that vegetation in North portion of NEB was also affected
by dryer conditions (Figure 4) (Montade et al., 2014). This allowed us to hypothesize that
changes in humidity during the last 2,000 yr were responsible for a disturbance in
vegetation that affected the ecological relationships related to food chain, increasing bats
competition for food, which resulted in bat population decline.
This period of bat population decline coincides with the Medieval Climate
Anomaly, described by Utida (unpublished) for Urubu Cave region, due to a North
displacement of the Intertropical Convergence Zone, registered by enriched values of ?18O
of Trapiá Cave speleothem and ?D of Boqueirão Lake sediments. More humid conditions
seems to be stable from 370 yr BP, as indicated by depleted ?18O values ~3.5‰ (Figure 4),
but bats returned to the cave only 158 yr after. This interval was probably the time that
180
plant population took to reestablish in the area, as well as for bats and insects that took
time to recolonize the area.
Another example of bat population decline affected by climate change is described
by Johnston et al. (2010) in East Europe as a result of changes in temperature. Bats
colonized caves during the MCA, a warm period, but not during Little Ice Age, a cold
period, represented as a hiatus in guano accumulation.
CONCLUSIONS
Sedimentological and chronological studies of cave sediments from Urubu Cave
allow us to associate their formation with precipitation events linked to solar variations on
orbital time scales. The upward of phreatic zones was responsible for transport and deposit
sediments from the drainages to inside the cave conducts of Urubu Cave during this period
of wetter conditions in NEB. A transitional period from humid to dry conditions was
responsible for environmental changes that resulted in soil denudation driven by fire, and
posterior soil erosion by precipitation. Lowering of phreatic systems allowed bat guano
preservation inside Urubu Cave until an intensification of dry conditions around 1,000 yr
BP, when impacts on vegetation, registered in pollen data, diminished food source of bat
population, which was reduced, reflected as a lower guano accumulation. A completely bat
population decline occurred 300 years after this impact that may also correspond to the
time of vegetation response to reduction in wet conditions. Return in wetter conditions
increased from 400 years BP to the Recent, but bat guano restarts accumulation after 200
years, when wetter conditions became more stable.
